comment: I suggest we just say 'address' term: this actually means 'no good person', and is part of a system widespread in Australia where men should use a highly negative word to address their sister, as a type of incest avoidenace. Also, for consistency shouldn't we also ask for the IPA version of this type of kin term as well (which would be bijweʔ
The form kaɲwoʔ was not given by MT but is given in Alpher 1982 with the meaning 'mDC, mZSC'

It will be observed that although the term kakkak covers both types of parallel grandparents – FF and MM – their reciprocals are not the same, since the recip. Of kakkak FF is kakkak (i.e. this sense is self-reciprocal) while the recip. Of kakkak MM is winjkûn(djan)
Normally, the basic 'father' term bulu is used for FeB and FyB. However, if more precision is required, the term buluwurrungu can be used for FeB
Normally, the basic 'father' term bulu is used for FeB and FyB. However, if more precision is required, the term bulukorroh can be used for FyB
nabadjan lit. meangs 'the big one' (male), and parallels the use of ngalbadjan to mean 'mother' in Bininj Kun-wok, where ngal- is the feminine prefix, hence 'the big one (female)'
Normally, the basic 'mother' term nah is used for M and MyZ. However, if more precision is required, the term nahkorroh can be used for MyZ
Normally, the basic 'father' term bulu is used for FeB and FyB. However, if more precision is required, the term buluwurrungu can be used for FeB
Normally, the basic 'father' term bulu is used for FeB and FyB. However, if more precision is required, the term bulukorroh can be used for FyB
